tasks.task: Performing Soil Crop Rotation and Disease Management
subtasks: Understanding the importance of crop rotation for soil health and disease prevention
Identifying soil-borne pests and diseases and their host plants
Determining the appropriate rotation sequence for specific crops (e.g., potato, onion, carrot) to manage common pests and diseases (e.g., verticillium, fungal pathogens, nematodes)
Adjusting the rotation plan based on the presence and level of infestation of specific pests and diseases
Incorporating cover crops (e.g., Tagetes partula, Japanese oat, summer barley) to manage nematode populations and improve soil structure
Considering the nitrogen fixing ability of leach crops and deep-rooted crops (e.g., summer barley) to optimize soil fertility
Utilizing the Best for Soil database to design and evaluate crop rotation plans based on local soil and pest conditions
Ensuring the inclusion of cover crops to maintain soil health and prevent nutrient leaching
Regularly soil analyzing for the presence of pests and diseases to adapt the rotation plan accordingly
Determining the infestation level of nematodes and fungal pathogens in the soil
Using specialized laboratories for accurate soil analyses if public services are unavailable

tasks.task: Managing Nematode Populations in Crop Rotation
subtasks: Identifying non-host plants for specific nematodes
Utilizing resistant cover crops (e.g., Tagetes partula) to control nematode populations
Alternating crops with known nematode populations (e.g., rye, Japanese oat) to manage population growth

tasks.task: Utilizing Cover Crops for Soil Health and Disease Management
subtasks: Selecting appropriate cover crops based on local soil conditions and pest management needs
Planting cover crops after main crops to prevent soil erosion and maintain soil fertility
Managing the timing of cover crop planting to optimize soil benefits (e.g., sowing by October 1st)
Considering the role of cover crops in enhancing soil aggregates and promoting microbial activity

tasks.task: Optimizing Crop Sequencing for Soil Fertility and Structure
subtasks: Rotating crops with different root depths to improve soil structure and nutrient availability
Incorporating deep-rooted crops (e.g., summer barley) after shallow-rooted crops (e.g., sugar beet) to access subsoil nutrients
Alternating crops with high nitrogen demand (e.g., lejeune forage crops) with crops that benefit from excess nitrogen (e.g., nitrogen fixing crops)
